newsitem.title: FRANCE: French mail order mogul found guilty of fraud.
newsitem.headline: French mail order mogul found guilty of fraud.

text.p: A French court on Friday found a mail order sales mogul guilty of fraud for selling useless "miracle" gadgets and failing to deliver on promises of enticing prizes.
The court in the southeastern city of Grasse handed Bernard Graeff, 48, a two-year suspended jail term, fined him 200,000 francs ($34,500) and barred him from the mail order business for five years.
It also ordered him to pay 2,500 francs ($430) to each of 1,382 disappointed clients, for a total of more than 3.4 million francs ($590,000).
In all, some 15,000 customers filed complaints against Graeff's firm, France Direct Service, which has since gone bankrupt and is operating under judicial supervision.
During Graeff's trial in November, Prosecutor Guy Robert contended the firm had "promised fabulous gains through various games in order to sell goods which were mostly poor-quality imported gadgets".
"You became rich on the backs of people with little means and you stole their dreams as well," Robert said.
Graeff was accused of leading customers to believe they would automatically win cars or exotic holidays if they ordered his goods.

His offerings, including rotating television antennas, singing birds and sauna-effect pyjamas for slimmers, were often simply never delivered. In other cases, customers received a pocket gadget closer to a stapler than to the sewing machine they had expected.
